Award.AwardTitle: Fractal NanoArchitectures: Design, Assembly and Properties
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division supports Prof. George R. Newkome of The University of Akron to investigate fractal nano- and macroscale molecules (self-similar components at differing size scales) based on multicomponent, supramolecular, directed and self-assembly protocols that rely on terpyridine-metal-terpyridine building block connectivity. The ability to incorporate site-specific, multiple metal centers into a predesigned molecular array or network affords a method to fine-tune the desired physical and chemical properties of the molecular fractals. The potential to introduce and exchange differing metals within the fractal framework, either during or after construction, will facilitate the study of precisely designed multimetal ensembles that have ramifications in molecular electronics, self-repairing frameworks, and antenna incorporation at the nanoscopic level. Precise pattern-based molecular structures are also envisioned. Use of these charged, polymetal lattices for composite fiber formation, based on alternating charged species will be investigated with increasingly higher generation fractal-based materials. Physical properties and uses envisioned involve energy storage and release, molecular electronic devices, data storage, solar cell nanocomponents, sensor and optical display capabilities, molecular antennas, and metamaterials.

New materials comprised of repeating similar shapes of differing sizes (termed "fractal") held together by metal glue-like interactions will be assembled, based on their components interactions, such as their potential to fit, pack, and associate in an orderly manner. This will lead to new types of macromolecules for use in electronic devices and components, such as with batteries for energy storage, switches in electric circuits, and antennas in miniature communication devices. Educational opportunities arise from the training and development of students and scientists at all academic levels. Educational outreach is promoted through regular presentations at regional, national and international public and private schools, universities, and conferences. Industrial and international collaborations continue to enhance this research through personnel and information exchange.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An overall perspective of this project incorporates functionalized, nanomolecular design and construction that integrates the spatial arts, mathematics, and material science. Fractal, or self-similar, motifs at different molecular scales lay a foundation for this work.

This work strives to ellucidate the self-assembly properties related specifically to the construction of fractal-based, macro- and nano-scale molecular architectures and more broadly to perfect macromolecular materials. The work is based on the well-known tenets founded in supramolecular and iterative chemistries with foundations in mathematic, artistic and geometric platforms that provide a focused pathways for project goals and targets. Envisioned projects are predicated on: (1) logically constructed, metal-connected components leading to precise architectures; (2) the incorporation of coordinated, intersecting features and components within shape-selective building blocks and components that facilitate single step, quantitative routes to nano- and mega-molecular materials; (3) systematic studies into the construction of 2D and 3D materials possessing precisely positioned utilitarian heterogeneous metal centers; (4) utility of the multifaceted, physicochemical properties available from the balanced interplay of organometallic and supramolecular regimes; (5) crafting self-assembled, structurally perfect constructs capable of large specie encapsulation to facilitate control of otherwise difficult to achieve properties; and (6) examination of the characteristics and mechanisms related to controlled nanomolecular reorganization via precise self-assembly-reassembly processes. Examples of structures and assemblies that have been crafted during this project to address these goals are exemplified in Figures 1 -5. 

Advancement of discovery and understanding of the proposed work promoted the integration of student training and enrichment, at all education levels, including K-12, undergraduate, graduate, post-doctoral, and visiting scientists (national and international), by providing appropriately staged conceptual and technical scientific challenges. This has facilitated student competence while instilling and nurturing specific elements of critical thinking – a requisite for all disciplines. Participation of underrepresented groups and minorities was encouraged through direct support and community outreach projects, as well as included inner-city school presentations and K-12 teacher involvement that broadly promote scientific and technical understanding. Additionally, scientific information concerning dendritic, macromolecular, nanomolecular, and fractal materials, in particular, is promulgated through the principal investigator's website, which currently averages approximately 6,000 visits per month. A searchable database currently comprised of nearly 16,000 references related to supramolecular, nanoscale and more recently megamolecular chemistries is available.

The Akron-Cleveland metroplex has ca. 6 million residents (a 500 mile radius encompasses 42 % of the US and 40 % of the Canadian populations). This comprises a broadly diverse workforce (with unique chemistry-related opportunities) with ca. 2000 polymer and chemical companies within 100 miles of this university. Work related to this project enhances the regional N.E. Ohio workforce through research, training, presentations, and education, while augmenting the mission of The University of Akron and the U.S. scientific and education agendas.

Commercialization of discoveries and technologies arising from this work is facilitated by the University of Akron Research Foundation and Office of Technology Transfer, in association with the newly formed Akron Commercialization Hub and Materials Experiment Station that are committed to the aggressive marketing of The University of Akron's research to enhance economic development.

 


Last Modified: 10/10/2016
Modified by: George R Newkome

Images (1 of )
  • Four-membered, 'Dondorff' rings prepared from bisterpyridine buildiing blocks resemble the graceful manta ray. Construction methods allow the crafting of site-specific multimetal placement as depicted in the computer generated, molecular models.
    Chem. Eur. J. 2012, 18, 11569
    Copyrighted
    George R Newkome
    Figure 1.
  • Cartoon images showing the self-assembly of two different bisterpyridine building blocks to give a molecular rhombus. Incorporation of a central arm (depicted in yellow) quantitatively affords the desired structure, whereas without it byproducts are formed.
    Chem. Commun. 2012, 48, 9873-9875.
    Copyrighted
    George R Newkome
    Figure 2.
  • Cartoon depicting the reversible, concentration-triggered, architectural rearrangement of a bisrhombus to two equivalents of a tetrahedron. We have since reported other examples of molecular rearrangements.
    J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2014, 136, 18149-18155.
    Copyrighted
    George R Newkome
    Figure 3.
  • A depiction of the thought process that leads from dendritic to fractal architecture. Envisioning the branched molecule (top left) to be flatened, then bifurcated and with succesively larger triangles transforms the initial structure into the (red molecular model) Sierpinski triangle.
    Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. 2014, 53,12182-12185
    George R Newkome
    Figure 4.
  • Images of the crystal structure of a cuboctahedron that was assembled in a single step. Views of different faces of a single molecule (5a-b) show its cubic and hexagonal shapes. Aggregate views (5c-d) show crystal packing. It undergoes new fission and fusion rearrangement to a tetrahedron.
    Angew. Chem. 2015, 54, 9224-9229
    Copyrighted
    George R Newkome
    Figure 5.
